questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a cartilaginous joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intervertebral disc joint

The intervertebral discs are pads of largely fibrocartilage that bind together the bodies of adjacent vertebrae.

questions.text: Bones are often classified according to their shape and/or developmental pattern. Which of the following choices is an example of a flat bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sternum

The sternum (breastbone) and the bones that form the cranial roof, or calvaria, are flat bones. These bones are typically located subcutaneously and are easily accessible.

questions.text: Which structure is derived from the same embryonic primordium as the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gonad

Both the kidneys and the gonads are derived from the intermediate mesoderm. This longitudinal dorsal ridge of mesoderm forms the urogenital ridge, which is involved with the formation of the future kidneys and gonads.

questions.text: Which of the following locations is ideal for placement of the stethoscope for auscultation of the tricuspid valve of the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Area C

The ideal placement of the stethoscope for auscultation of the tricuspid valve is at the 5th intercostal space slightly to the left of the sternal border, identified by the letter “C” in the photo. The tricuspid valve separates the right atrium and the right ventricle.

questions.text:
An 21-year-old male is cut severely on the lateral wall of his right chest during a knife fight duFollowing healing, his scapula moves away from
the thoracic wall when he leans on his right hand, giving the appearance indicated in the given photo. Which of the following nerves is likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Long thoracic nerve

The photo demonstrates a case of “winged scapula,” indicative of a lesion of the long thoracic nerve and subsequent paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old retired professional cyclist, who still rides his bike 400 miles per week, comes to his physician complaining of hand problems.
Physician notices shown finding during examination. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ulnar nerve

This is presentation of “handlebar neuropathy” presents with hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints of the fourth and fifth fingers. The “clawing” of these two fingers is accompanied by sensory loss in the medial side of the hand. The ulnar nerve can become compressed between the pisiform and hook of the hamate at the wrist in a condition termed “ulnar canal syndrome” or “Guyon tunnel syndrome.”

questions.text:
The given X-ray reveals a fracture of the proximal humerus, indicated by the black arrow. Given the location of the fracture, what artery is most likely
damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Posterior circumflex humeral artery

The radiograph shows a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. The posterior humeral circumflex artery, accompanied by the axillary nerve, lies against the posterior aspect of the surgical neck as it passes into the quadrangular space of the shoulder.

questions.text: All of the following pairs for adult derivatives of embryonic structures is correct EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Umbilical artery: Lateral umbilical ligament
• Umbilical arteries become medial umbilical ligaments.
• Lateral umbilical ligaments are raised by the inferior epigastric arteries.
• Median umbilical ligament is raised by urachus attaching to the apex of urinary bladder.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman comes into your family practice office because she says she is losing weight and she is  having trouble chewing. Which of the following muscles is a depressor of the
jaw?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lateral pterygoid muscle

The lateral pterygoid muscle depresses the mandible and opens the mouth when assisted by the anterior belly of the digastric muscle and the mylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: Abnormal persistence of which of the following cells from primitive streak result in shown abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Primordial germ cells

Teratomas may arise from PGCs (or from epiblast cells),which are pluripotent cells. Therefore, within teratomas are present derivatives of all three germ layers & may include skin, bone, teeth, gut tissue.

questions.text:
During a viva you are asked to identify the rostral end of the corpus callosum which is marked in the radiographic image shown. Correct
answer would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Splenium

Body of corpus callosum is arched; its anterior curved portion, the genu, continues antero ventrally as the rostrum. The thick posterior portion terminates in curved splenium, which lies over midbrain.

questions.text: Marked structure develops from which of the following structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4th Pharyngeal arch

Marked structure is which epiglottis arises from fourth pharyngeal arch. It can be seen as distinct structure later than other cartilage of the pharynx, visible around the fifth month of development.

questions.text: Which structure passes through an arrow marked foramen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Middle meningeal artery

Arrow marked foramen is Foramen spinosum and it gives passage to middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Transversalis fascia

The deep inguinal ring, through which the round ligament or spermatic cord enters the inguinal canal, is a defect in the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery in the diagram:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior communicating artery

The marked artery is posterior communicating artery, branch of internal carotid artery, anastomosing with posterior cerebral artery, contributing to circle of Willis. This is inferior view of brain, showing the circle of Willis in the interpeduncular fossa at the base of the brain.

questions.text: A newborn is having a congenital defect as shown in the image. During the ascent of the kidney, the fused portion at the lower aspect of the kidney is arrested by which vessel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inferior mesenteric artery

The horseshoe kidney's ascent is often quoted to be held back by the inferior mesenteric artery at L3 however, the horseshoe kidney can also be found lower in the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Facilitated diffusion

The given image shows the transport of a molecule across a membrane with the help of a carrier protein. This form of transport is called facilitated diffusion. When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text:
A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following
findings is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

The above clinical scenario of transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm. The fibers in the dorsal column are organized in such a way that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

choices.text: Maximum reabsorption in loop of henle
Maximum water absorption take place in collecting duct
Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about renal tubular transport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

Glucose and amino acids completely reabsorbed in the PCT. Maximum reabsorption take place in the PCT. Some amount (Approx. 52%) of urea absorption occur in PCT and secreted in the thin ascending loop of Henle. Maximum water reabsorption take place in the pct

questions.text:
A patient presents to the ER with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination his vitals are stable, but he could not speak. He had no other neurological findings, had normal
handwriting skills, and could understand what was being asked of him to which he responds by nodding. Where could be the lesion for this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Broca's area

Broca's area is the most likely to be involved as only speech production is affected here. Wernicke's area works to make sure the language makes sense, whilst Broca's area helps to ensure the language is produced in a fluent way.

questions.text: Which of the following is major surfactant producing cell in lungs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type 2 pneumocyte

Type 1 pneumocytes are alveolar cells that line the alveolar surfaceAnd help in gas exchange
Type 2 pneumocytes are alveolar cells that secrete surfactant proteins to reduce surface tension.

questions.text: Which of the following would help in explaining the mechanism of action of  atrial natriuretic peptide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

cGMP

Atrial natriuretic peptide act via cGMP. cAMP Is a second messenger for the hormone which mainly concerned with metabolism, electrolyte secretion, and water reabsorption.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The P02 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PC02 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Equal to dead space

VA/Q = infinity means that there is no espxcahcaen. ge of 02 & CO2· which equals to dead
VA represents the ventilation in alveoli and Q represents the blood flow through the alveolus. The
ratio of VA and Q explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar
ventilation and alveolar blood flow. The ventilation-perfusion ratio is considered normal if there is an
equal amount of blood flow & ventilation through the alveolus.

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Heparan sulfate

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins. Collagen type IV, fibronectin, entactin are structural components of basement membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Factor 2

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.
Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, Xis done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues.
This is done by the enzyme glutamyl carboxylase with the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cushing's disease

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.
Cushing's disease is caused by an ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma. The increased ACTH causes
increased cortisol production.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin B12 deficiency

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin 812 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin 812.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Insulin
Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signalling to exert its functions.
Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes
• Growth hormone
• Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
• Prolactin
• Leptin

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enterogastric
In the enterogastric reflex, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum.  When the food enters the duodenum, multiple reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall which passes back to the stomach. These reflexes slow or stop the stomach emptying if the volume of the chyme in the duodenum becomes too much. These reflexes are called enterogastric reflexes.

questions.text: Which of the following structures will have the slowest rate of conduction of the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-V bundle fibers

The atrial and ventricular muscles have a relatively rapid rate of conduction of the cardiac action potential, and the anterior internodal pathway also has fairly rapid conduction of the impulse. 

However, the A-V bundle myofibrils have a slow rate of conduction because their sizes are considerably smaller than the sizes of the normal atrial and ventricular muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following capillaries has the highest capillary permeability to plasma albumin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Liver

The liver endothelium contains many open pores, or fenestrae that allow extremely large molecules such as albumin to pass in or out of the liver tissues. Under normal conditions, very lile if any albumin cross the capillary walls of muscle, glomerular, brain, or intestine

questions.text: Which diuretic inhibits Na+-2Cl − - K+ co-transport in the loop of Henle as its primary action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Furosemide

Furosemide is a powerful inhibitor of the Na+-2Cl − -K+ co-transporter in the loop of Henle. Thiazide diuretics primarily inhibit NaCl reabsorption into the distal tubule, whereas carbonic anhydrase inhibitors decrease bicarbonate reabsorption in the tubules. Amiloride inhibits sodium channel activity, whereas spironolactone inhibits the action of mineralocorticoids in the renal tubules.

questions.text: What is the term for binding of IgG and complement to an invading microbe to facilitate recognition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Opsonization

Phagocytosis of bacteria is enhanced by the presence on their surfaces of both immunoglobulin and products of the complement cascade, which in turn bind to surface receptors on phagocytes. This “tagging” of bacteria and other particles for enhanced phagocytosis is called opsonization.

questions.text: The basic rhythm of respiration is generated by neurons located in the medulla. What limits the duration of inspiration and increases respiratory rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pneumotaxic center

The pneumotaxic center transmits signals to the dorsal respiratory group that “switch off” inspiratory signals, thus controlling the duration of the filling phase of the lung cycle. This has a secondary effect   of increasing the rate of breathing because limitation of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of respiration.

choices.text: Blackish soot deposit on posterior part of tongue
Singeing of eyebrows and facial hair

questions.text:
A 38 years old female presented to the emergency with extensive burns. The patient had grade 3 burns on the face, back, upper arms and forearms along with singeing of hairs. Which of
the following is not a proof of inhalation burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Yellow colored sputum

Yellow sputum/ phlegm = Mostly a sign of bacterial infection. In burns takes time to develop. Grade 3 burns: Sputum with carbonaceous colored. Singeing of facial hair, burns on face, soot marks & singed eyebrows or facial hair- Indicative of acute burns inhalational injury. Features of inhalation injury: Characteristic: History of fire in an enclosed space. Burns of face. Singed nasal & facial hair. Inflamed pharyngeal mucosa.

choices.text: Gutter fracture skull with cervical spine injury
Pond fracture skull with cervical spine injury
Depressed fracture skull with cervical spine injury
Ring fracture of foramen magnum with lumbar spine injury

questions.text: A man fell down from a height of 35 feet. Eyewitnesses say that he landed on his feet. Which of the following injury is possible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ring fracture of foramen magnum with lumbar spine injury

Ring fracture: Commonly used to signify any fracture around foramen magnum. Refers to fissured fracture about 3.5 cm outside foramen magnum at back. Involves middle ear laterally & roof of nose anteriorly. Rare & requires increased production of force. Causes: Fall from a height on feet or buttocks. Sudden violent turn of head on spine. Severe blow on vertex driving skull downwards on  vertebral column. Heavy blow directed underneath occiput or chin.

questions.text: Based on the shown finding shown in a patient brought dead to the ED by ambulance what can be estimated time of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3-4 hours

Tache noire (French, black line): If the eyelids remain open for 3-4 hours after death, there is formation of two yellow triangles (base on the limbus, apex at the lateral or medial canthus and sides are formed by the margins of the upper and lower eyclids) on the sctera at each side of the iris, which become brown and then black.

questions.text: A person is liable for punishment for perjury which is defined under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Section 193 of IPC

A person is liable for punishment for perjury, which is defined under section 193 of IPC. Section 191 IPC defines perjury and section 193 IPC describes the punishment. "Perjury means giving willful false evidence. The witness is liable to be prosecuted for perjury and the imprisonment may extend up to 7
years (Section 193, IPC).

questions.text: There is a case of infanticide. During the post-mortem examination, the doctor performs Breslau's second life test. This test detects changes in which of the following organ:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stomach and intestine

Breslau's Second Life Test (Stomach Bowel test) Principle: It assumes that a live born child would respire and therefore would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. Thus detecting the presence of air in stomach and intestine (positive test) proves live birth (even in absence of positive hydrostatic lung test if there had been some obstruction in respiratory However, negative test (absence of air in stomach and bowel) does not always mean still-birth since air does not necessarily enter stomach in adequate amounts during act of breathing.

questions.text: Surgical alteration or suturing of gunshot wounds may create problems in distinguishing entry from exit. This is called as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Kennedy phenomenon

Surgical alteration or suturing of gunshot wounds creates problems. The evaluation of the wound, whether it was an entrance or an exit wound becomes difficult.

questions.text:
A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the
thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ligature strangulation

The most likely cause of death in a case where the ligature is completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid, with no saliva dribbling, is ligature strangulation. Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

questions.text:
During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading
questions are not allowed in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cross examination

Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to a psychiatrist with a history of recurrent and persistent sexual fantasies and behaviors. He reports a strong and recurrent urge to touch or rub his
genitals against non-consenting strangers in crowded places such as buses or subway trains. He acknowledges that these acts cause significant distress to the victims, but he
is unable to control his impulses. The patient is otherwise functioning well in his personal and professional life. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Frotteurism

Frotteurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by recurrent and intense sexual fantasies, urges, or behaviors involving touching or rubbing one's genitals against non-consenting individuals. The key feature of frotteurism is the act of rubbing against others without their consent. These acts typically occur in crowded places where the offender can blend in and avoid detection.

questions.text: Fracture clavicle all the following are used for treatment except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bone grafting

Treatment for fracture clavicle is usually non operative but can be operated and fixation method can be plating or k wire fixation.Bone graft is usually not required for fracture clavicle.

choices.text: Terminal slip of extensor tendon to distal phalanx
Terminal slip of flexor tendon to distal phalanx
Terminal slip of flexor tendon to proximal phalanx
Terminal slip of extensor tendon to proximal phalanx

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic after jamming his finger while playing basketball. He is unable to fully  extend his left index finger at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. On
examination, there is tenderness over the dorsal aspect of the DIP joint and the finger is held in a flexed position. X-ray imaging shows no evidence of bony injury. What is the most likely
anatomical structure involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Terminal slip of extensor tendon to distal phalanx

Mallet finger, also known as baseball finger, occurs due to an avulsion or rupture of the extensor tendon at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. It commonly occurs when the finger is forcibly flexed while the extensor tendon is under tension. Patients with mallet finger present with  an inability to extend the finger at the DIP joint and the finger is held in a flexed position. This injury primarily  involves the terminal slip of the extensor tendon, which attaches to the distal phalanx.

questions.text: In a newborn child, abduction and internal rotation produces a click sound. It is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Otorolani’s sign

ORtolani is test of reduction of hip by abduction of hip Barlows is test of dislocation of hip by adduction

questions.text:
A 5 year girl complaints of pain & swelling middle of right thigh. History of fever is present. Swelling has local temperature raised. X-ray shows: Onion peel periosteal reaction and codmans
triangle and histopathology has round cells, glycogen positive and MIC 2 positive:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ewings sarcoma

1st decade of life,diaphyseal lesion with presentation similar to infection points towards ewings also ewings is a round cell tumor, cells are glycogen positive and MIC 2 positive.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presents with a limp and pain in the right hip that has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. On examination, there is limited range of motion and decreased
internal rotation of the right hip. Which investigation is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

The investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of Perthes disease in this case is Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).

questions.text: A 4-month-old child having complaints of high-grade fever, decreased appetite and pain right hip. On examination he has dehydration, tenderness in scarpas triangle, swelling in right hip region/absent movements in right hip region. On X-ray there is mild increase in medial joint space. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Septic arthritis

Patient is in first 5 years of life with absent movement at joint with toxic presentation goes towards septic arthritis.

questions.text: In which of the following condition does oxygen dissociation curve shifts to right?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anemia

questions.text: The shown brace is used in which condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Developmental displacement hypoplasia

The Pavlik harness is a soft splint. It is most commonly used for treating infants with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

questions.text: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Divalent Metal Transporter 1

Transport of Fe2+ into the enterocytes occurs via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1), through an active transport process.Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes in the initial part of the duodenum. DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substances like zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese.

questions.text: A 37 year old man is operated for a lipoma on his left arm. The swelling is excised with clear linear incision and the wound is sutured cleanly by an intern. In this type of healing, neovascularization reaches its peak on day	?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5
The scenario given is an example of healing by first intention. By day 5 of healing by the first intention, neovascularization reaches its peak. as granulation tissue fills incision space. An example of healing by first intention is the healing of a clean uninfected surgical incision sutured.

choices.text: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular content
It is associated with adjacent inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true statement for apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Plasma membrane is intact

Plasma membrane is intact in apoptosis. Apoptosis is a pathway of programmed cell death. Enzymatic digestion, adjacent inflammation and karyolysis are features of necrosis.

questions.text: A young boy is being evaluated for developmental delay, mild autism,and mental retardation. Physical exam- ination reveals the boy to have large,everted ears and a long face with a large mandible. He is also found to have macroorchidism (large testes), and extensive workup reveals multiple tandem repeats of the nucleotide sequence CGG in his DNA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fragile X syndrome

A Fragile X syndrome ; The fragile X syndrome, which is more common in males than females, is one of the most common causes of familial mental retardation. Additional clinical features of this disorder include developmental delay, a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears, and large testicles
(macroorchidism).Examination of the DNA from patients with fragile X syndrome reveals multiple tandem repeats of the nucleotide sequence CGG on the X chromosome. Normally these repeats average up to 50 in number, but in patients with fragile X syndrome there are more than 230 repeats.
This number of repeats is called a full mutation. Normal transmitting males and carrier females have between 50 and 230 CGG repeats. This number of repeats is called a premutation.

questions.text: An autopsy is performed on a 64- year-old man who died of congestive heart failure. Sections of the liver reveal yellow-brown granules in the cytoplasm of most of the hepatocytes. Which of the following stains would be most useful to demonstrate with positive staining that these yellow-brown cytoplasmic granules are in fact composed of hemosiderin (iron)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prussian blue stain

Prussian blue stain ; The differential for brown (or yellow-brown) granules in hepatocytes as seen with routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain includes hemosiderin, bile, and lipofuscin. The special histologic stain for hemosiderin, which contains iron, is the Prussian blue stain. Hemosiderin stains blue with a Prussian blue stain. Causes of excess iron deposition in the liver include hemosiderosis, which can result from excessive blood transfusions, and familial hemochromatosis, which results from excessive iron absorption from the gut. In contrast, excess bile in the liver can be seen with jaundice, while lipofuscin deposition is seen with aging, cachexia, and severe malnutrition.

questions.text: An old man underwent a bone marrow examination which revealed the presence of the finding shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis of the affected individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Multiple myeloma

Given image is of Mott cell seen in Multiple myeloma.Mott cells are plasma cells that have spherical inclusions packed in their cytoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is likely diagnosis for the patient looking at the karyotype given in the image :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Edward Syndrome

The given karyotype is of Edward Syndrome. As there is trisomy of Chromosome 18.

questions.text: Pyogenic bacterial infections and ischemic brain infarcts most characteristically produce which one of the listed types of necrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liquefactive necrosis

Explanation: Liquefactive necrosis is the type of necrosis produced by acute bacterial infections. With liquefactive necrosis the dead cells are completely dissolved by hydrolytic enzymes from acute inflammatory cells and all that remains is a liquid mass. Liquefactive necrosis can also be seen with fungal infections,and it is the type of necrosis that is produced by ischemic necrosis of the brain

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease dies of congestive heart failure. The brain at autopsy is shown in the image. This patient’s brain exemplifies which of the following responses to chronic injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atrophy

Clinically, atrophy is recognized as diminution in the size or function of an organ. It is often seen in areas of vascular insufficiency or chronic inflammation and may result from disuse. Atrophy may be thought of as an adaptive response to stress, in which the cell shuts down its differentiated functions. Reduction in the size of an organ may reflect reversible cell atrophy or may be caused by irreversible loss of cells. For example, atrophy of the brain in this patient with Alzheimer disease is secondary to extensive cell death, and the size of the organ cannot be restored. This patient’s brain shows marked atrophy of the frontal lobe. The gyri are thinned, and sulciare widened. Anaplasia (choice A) represents lack of differentiated features in a neoplasm. Diagnosis: Alzheimer disease, atrophy

choices.text: Vasodilation - stasis - transient vasoconstriction - increased permeability
Transient vasoconstriction- increased permeability - Vasodilation - stasis
Transient vasoconstriction - Vasodilation - stasis - increased permeability
Transient vasoconstriction - Vasodilation - increased permeability- stasis

questions.text: Sequence of events occurring in acute inflammation :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Transient vasoconstriction - Vasodilation - increased permeability- stasis Transient vasoconstriction - Vasodilation- increased permeability-stasis

questions.text: Macrophages play an important role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation. Which of the following cells perform the same function in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Kupffer cell

Explanation: Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer–Browicz cells, are specialized cells localized in liver within the lumen of the liver sinusoids and are adhesive to their endothelial cells which make up the blood vessel walls. Kupffer cells contain the largest amount of tissue-resident macrophages in the body

questions.text: A 69 year old patient presents with the chief complaint of fatigue and lower back pain and a headache for the past few weeks. Lab investigations revealed elevated values of ESR and radiograph shows the presence of multiple punched out lesions in the skull. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serum electrophoresis showing IgG

Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Multiple Myeloma. The Mott cell is seen above in hematoxylin and eosin staining of myeloma contains cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russel bodies. Inclusions conting Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russel bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma. Plasma cells containing globular cytoplasmic inclusions composed of immunoglobulins are known as Mott cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man experiences chest pain a few days ago. He now has increased difficulty in breathing and unstable vitals, the gross appearance of his interventricular myocardium is shown in the image below. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Coagulative necrosis

Explanation: The above image shows coagulative necrosis. In this type of necrosis the cells are dead but the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved. The image shows ischemic injury to the heart.

choices.text: Increased growth of capillary endothelial cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless lesion on her right ear lobe as shown in the image below. She reports that her ears were pierced 4 months ago. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Excessive production of extracellular matrix

Keloid is an exuberant scar that tends to progress beyond the site of the initial injury and recurs after excision.

choices.text: Defective aggregation of platelets in response to agonists

questions.text: Wiskott Aldrich all are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

AR inheritance

Explanation: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is inherited in an X-linked recessive disease

questions.text: Which of the following characterizes an eczematous reaction that occurs 72 hours after wearing latex gloves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type IV reaction

Explanation: Sensitization to latex has become a major healthcare problem. Local skin irritations are common but more severe allergic reactions occur, up to and including rare anaphylactic reactions that are occasionally fatal. The immune responses to latex are immediate-type hypersensitivity (type I) reactions, expressing themselves in minutes, or delayed-type hypersensitivity (type IV) reactions that express themselves in 48-72 hours

questions.text: A young man met with a motor bike accident and had injury to ileum and jejunum. Therefore the entire ileum and partial jejunum was resected. Which of the following would the patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation: Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine.

choices.text: Persistent diarrhea after a 48 hour fast
Onset of symptoms during a period of stress

questions.text: A 37 year old male presented to the OPD with a 18 days history of crampy abdominal pain associated with diarrhea. Which of the following features supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Onset of symptoms during a period of stress

Explanation: Abnormal psychiatric features are recorded in up to 80% of IBS patients, especially in referral centers; however, no single psychiatric diagnosis predominates. Most of these patients demonstrated exaggerated symptoms in response to visceral distention, and this abnormality persists even after exclusion of psychological factors. Psychological factors influence pain thresholds in IBS patients, as stress alters sensory thresholds. An association between prior sexual or physical abuse and development of IBS has been reported. Clinical studies suggest that IBS has a strong developmental component which involves interactions of genetic and epigenetic factors early in life. These may modulate brain networks related to emotional arousal and/ or central autonomic control, salience and somatosensory integration. Abuse is associated with greater pain reporting, psychological distress, and poor health outcome

questions.text: What is the most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Painless hematuria

Explanation: The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria. Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria and, sometimes, as the only clinical manifestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of the clinical combination of generalized edema, hypoalbuminemia,  and hypercholesterolemia in an adult whose urinalysis demonstrated marked proteinuria, with fatty casts and oval fat bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephrotic syndrome ; Glomerular diseases may clinically produce either nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by marked proteinuria, that is, proteinuria greater than 3.5 g/24 h. Because of this marked proteinuria, patients lose albumin (hypoalbuminemia), which leads to peripheral edema.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with low back pain and stiffness. Radiographic examination finds extensive calcification of the vertebral and paravertebral ligaments, producing a “bamboo spine.” Rheumatoid factor is not identified in his peripheral blood. This patient’s abnormalities are most likely the result of a disorder that is most closely associated with which one of the following HLA types?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HLA-B27

HLA is the association of ankylosing spondylitis with HLA-B27. Ankylosing spondylitis is one type of spondyloarthropathy that lacks the rheumatoid factor found in rheumatoid arthritis. An example of an inherited error of metabolism being associated with a certain HLA type is the association of hemochromatosis with HLA-A3 . Two examples of this are the associations of rheumatoid arthritis with DR4 and of insulin dependent diabetes with DR3/DR4.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with increasing fatigue, slight weight gain, and a low-grade fever. Approximately 3 weeks before developing these symptoms she had a 4-day upper respiratory viral infection. At present a physical examination finds a tender enlarged thyroid gland. If a biopsy specimen reveals granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

De Quervain thyroiditis

De Quervain (subacute) thyroiditis is a self-limited cause of hypothyroidism. It typically follows a viral infection when patients develop the acute onset of fever with painful enlargement of the thyroid gland. Patients may develop mild hyperthyroidism early, but later they usually develop hypothyroidism. De Quervain thyroiditis also is known as granulomatous thyroiditis because histologic sections will show granulomatous inflammation with giant cells surrounding fragments of colloid.

questions.text: A patient died of myocardial infraction & his heart was taken out & put in a solution. The normal area turned brick red whereas infracted portion turned white as shown in figure. Which of the following can likely be component of solution ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stains LDH 1. Normal heart has LDH1 so it shows Brick red colour in normal heart . In myocardial infracted LDH-1 is not present so it is pale.

questions.text: ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diabetes

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a history of frequent episodes of renal colic with high calcium renal stones. The most useful diuretic in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hydrochlorthiazide

Thiazides cause hypercalcemia by decreasing the renal excretion of Ca2+. These are useful in a patient having hypercalciurea. In such a patient, thiazides decrease the excretion of Ca2+ in the kidney and thus reduces the chances of stone formation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male, Jorawar Singh presented to the emergency with muscle weakness and cramping. He has been taking hydrochlorothiazide for recently diagnosed hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypokalemia

A decrease in the intravascular fluid volume stimulates aldosterone secretion and leads to increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions in the urine. This results in hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, which is a common side effect of most diuretics other than the potassium-sparing class. Hypokalemia manifests with muscle weakness and cramping.

choices.text: Acetazolamide is a carbonic acid anhydrase stimulant
Thiazides act on cortical diluting segment of nephron
Furosemide is a high ceiling diuretic

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about diuretics? (DPG 1997)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase stimulant

•	Acetazolamide is an inhibitor of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is taken during the first part of the meal for the purpose of delaying absorption of dietary carbohydrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acarbose

•	It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor.

•	It inhibits the breakdown of complex carbohydrates to simple carbohydrates and thus decreases
their absorption.

questions.text: A 15 year old girl with type 1 diabetes is brought to emergency complaining of dizziness. Laboratory findings include severe hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis and blood pH of 7.15. To achieve rapid control of severe ketoacidosis, appropriate drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Crystalline zinc insulin

Diabetic ketoacidosis must be managed by fast acting insulin preparations like
•	Regular insulin [crystalline zinc insulin]
•	Insulin lispro 
•	Insulin aspart

questions.text: The drug prednisolone is known to be a powerful antiinflammatory agent. This is true due to the action of the drug on which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phospholipase A

choices.text: Benzodiazepines activate GABAB receptors in the spinal cord
Benzodiazepines block glutamate receptors in neuronal pathways in the brain
They increase the frequency of opening of chloride ion channels that are coupled to GABAA receptors
They are direct acting GABA receptor agonists in the CNS

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

They increase the frequency of opening of chloride ion channels that are coupled to GABAA receptors

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not used in multiple sclerosis? (AIIMS Nov- 2011)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mycophenolate mofetil

FDA approved therapies for multiple sclerosis include:
•	Interferon beta-1a
•	Interferon beta-1b
•	Glatiramer
•	Natalizumab
•	Fingolimod
•	Mitoxantrone
•	Methylprednisolone

questions.text: Mechanism of action of donepezil is: (MH 2006)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Centrally acting reversible anticholinesterase

questions.text: Granulocytopenia, gingival hyper- plasia and facial hirsutism are all possible side effects of one of the following anticonvulsant drugs? (AI 2003)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phenytoin

questions.text: Drug of choice in nocturnal enuresis is: (UP 2008)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Imipramine

questions.text: A patient presents with malignant hyperthermia and metabolic acidosis. Immediate treatment should be started with
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intravenous dantrolene

The current treatment of choice for malignant hyperthermia is the intravenous administration of dantrolene
Other important measures are:
•	Discontinuation of triggering agents
•	Supportive therapy directed at correcting hyperthermia, acidosis, and organ dysfunction.

questions.text: Local anesthetics act by: (DPG 2006)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Affecting the Na+ channels

questions.text: A child presents with bladder exstrophy and chronic renal failure. The muscle relaxant of choice to be used during surgery of exstrophy in this child is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atracurium

Atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman’s elimination i.e. it does not require liver or kidney. It is the muscle relaxant of choice in hepatic and renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is given to treat thrombocytopenia secondary to anti-cancer therapy and is known to stimulate progenitor megakaryocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oprelvekin

Oprelvekin (1L-11) is used to prevent and treat thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A drug that binds to and inhibits Gp IIb/IIIa glycoprotein and is responsible for platelet antiaggregatory effects is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tirofiban

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GP IIb/IIIa) inhibitors prevent platelet aggregation by blocking glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors on their platelet's plasma membrane and inhibiting fibrinogen binding. The available GP IIb/IIIa inhibitors include tirofiban and eptifibatide.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with history of thorn prick, a year back has verrucous lesions in the skin with following microscopic findings; Identify the agent:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chromoblastomycosis

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by several different dematiaceous fungi and resulting in the formation of slow-growing warty plaques and cauliflower-like lesions which may ulcerate. The fungi produce thick-walled, single or multicellular clusters called sclerotic or muriform bodies, respectively.

questions.text: Prausnitz –Kustner reaction is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IgE
 
The Prausnitz-Küstner (P-K) reaction is a sensitive test for the presence and activity in the skin of immunoglobulin E, an important class of immunoglobulin mediating allergic reactions.

questions.text: Stimulatory hypersensitivity is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Modified type II hypersensitivity

Type II hypersensitivity reaction refers to an antibody-mediated immune reaction in which antibodies (IgG or IgM) are directed against cellular or extracellular matrix antigens, resulting in cellular destruction, functional loss, or damage to tissues. Damage can occur through multiple mechanisms.

questions.text: True regarding C4b2a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

C3 convertase in classical pathway

C3 convertase can be used to refer to the form produced in the alternative pathway (C3bBb) or the classical and lectin pathways (C4bC2b, formerly C4b2a).

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dark ground microscopy

Spirochetes bacteria observed under dark field microscopy. The entire field appears dark when there is no sample on the microscope stage; thus the name dark-field microscopy.

questions.text: DNA is detected by –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Southern blot

A Southern blot is a laboratory method used to detect specific DNA molecules from among a many other DNA molecules.

questions.text: Most common strain of E. coli giving rise to traveller’s diarrhoea is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is a type of Escherichia coli and one of the leading bacterial causes of diarrhea in the developing world, as well as the most common cause of travelers' diarrhea.

questions.text: Most important serotype of E. coli causing Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

O157: H7 of EHEC

HUS occurs as a complication of a diarrheal infection (usually E. coli O157:H7 EHEC infection).

questions.text: Friedlander’s bacillus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Klebsiella pneumoniae

Carl Friedlander described Klebsiella pneumoniae for the first time. He described it as an encapsulated bacillus after isolating the bacterium from the lungs of those who had died from pneumonia. Originally named Friedlander's bacillus, it was not until 1886 that the bacterium garnered the name Klebsiella.

questions.text: Selective medium for Shigella:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hektoen agar

Commonly used primary isolation media include MacConkey, Hektoen Enteric Agar, and Salmonella- Shigella (SS) Agar. These media contain bile salts to inhibit the growth of other Gram-negative bacteria and pH indicators to differentiate lactose fermenters (Coliforms) from non-lactose fermenters such as shigellae.

choices.text: O antigen of S.paratyphi is used
Felix tube is used for O agglutination

questions.text: True about Widal test:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

H-antigen is most immunogenic

Widal test detects agglutinating antibodies against the O and H antigens of S. Typhi. H-antigen is most immunogenic

questions.text: Identify the following staining method:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Albert staining

Albert's stain test is used to stain and observe metachromatic granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Albert stain is a kind of differential stain used for staining and identifying metachromatic granules. The granules appear purple-black when exposed to Albert's stain and against the light green cytoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following stimulate adenylate cyclase with G – protein coupled action:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cholera toxin
 
The G-protein, now trapped in its active state, continually activates adenylate cyclase, which in turn stimulates the production of cAMP. cAMP molecules activate protein kinase A (PKA), which in turn activates the opening of chloride ion channels and blocks the action of sodium-hydrogen antiporters.

questions.text: Ricketsial disease with positive Weil-Felix reaction by only OX -19:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epidemic typhus

Antigen suspension of Proteus OX 19 antigen reacts strongly with the sera of patients with typhus group rickettsiae and Rocky Mountain spotted fever, Proteus OX 2 with the sera of patients with spotted fever infections, while the Proteus OX K with the sera of patients infected with scrub typhus.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with fever, chest pain and dry cough, sputum cultured on charcoal yeast medium, the organism is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Legionella

Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) Agar is used for primary isolation and cultivation of Legionella pneumophila and other Legionella species from environmental samples and clinical specimens.

questions.text: Whooping cough is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

B. pertussis

Pertussis is caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis.[4] It is spread easily through the coughs and sneezes of an infected person.

questions.text: A 25 years old man presents with urethral discharge for the last three days. A Gram-stained smear of the discharge is shown in the figure. All of the following are true about the likely etiological agent except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Obligate intracellular

History of urethral discharge in a young male and in the given image, there is presence of Gram- negative cocci arranged in pairs (kidney shaped). The organism is Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is facultative intracellular organism, shows twitching motility. It is Catalase and oxidase positive. Pili are virulence factor for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

choices.text: She is trained for a period of 21 days
Works with the Village Health and Sanitation Committee
Act as depot holder for IFA, ORS
She is in the age group 25–45 years

questions.text: All of the following are true about ASHA except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

She is trained for a period of 21 days

The induction training of ASHA is for 23 days in 5 episodes spread over 1 year.

questions.text: 1 male health worker, 1 female health worker should be present at each PHC. This is given by which committee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Kartar Singh Committee

The main aim of the Kartar Singh committee was to study integrated services at the peripheral and supervisory levels and the feasibility of having MPW (multi-purpose worker) in the field. ANM is to be replaced by a female health worker and a basic health worker.

questions.text: As per revised IPHS guidelines, an Ophthalmologist is proposed for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Every 5 CHC

One Ophthalmologist (MS or Diploma in Ophthalmology) for every 5 CHCs is recommended in addition to existing Provisions. One Dental Surgeon, 6 GDMOS, one AYUSH specialist and one AYUSH general doctor are also recommended in this IPHS.

choices.text: 3 days before and 10 days after appearance of rashes
4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rashes

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a high fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes. After a few days, the child develops a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. Period of communicability of described condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rashes

Measles, also known as rubeola, is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus. It is characterized by a combination of symptoms, including high fever, cough, runny nose, red, watery eyes (conjunctivitis), and a distinctive rash.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is brought to a PHC with history of cough and cold. On examination, he has respiratory rate of 48 per minute and there is absence of chest indrawing. His weight is 5 kg. He is probably suffering from'
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Very severe pneumonia

Here the child has a weight 5 kg (Indicative of severe malnutrition- where typical signs of pneumonia are masked). Hence, it is a case of very severe pneumonia

choices.text: The initial phase is stabilisation phase.
F100 diet is catch up diet.
Iron, Vit A and Zn are given as supplements in starter diet.
F75 has lower protein compared to F100 diet.

questions.text: In Nutritional rehabilitation centres, all are correct EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Iron, Vit A and Zn are given as supplements in starter diet.

questions.text: Article 19, child protection from all forms of violence are safeguarded under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ICPS

The Integrated Child Protection Scheme (ICPS) is a centrally sponsored scheme aimed at building a protective environment for children in difficult circumstances, as well as other vulnerable children, through GovernmentCivil Society Partnership.

questions.text: Which anthropometric indicator is most commonly used to assess the nutritional status of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC)

Explanation: Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is a commonly used anthropometric indicator to assess the nutritional status of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

questions.text: Which MCH scheme in India includes the provision of free antenatal check-ups, cash incentives for institutional deliveries, and postnatal care for mothers and newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

National Rural Health Mission (NRHM)

Explanation: NRHM encompasses various initiatives aimed at improving maternal and child health, including antenatal and postnatal care, institutional deliveries, and more.

choices.text: It is associated with exposure under investigation
It is distributed equally in study and control groups
It is associated both with exposure and disease
It is related to matching in case control study

questions.text: Which one of the following is true regarding confounding factor except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It is distributed equally in study and control groups

Confounding factor” is associated both with exposure and disease, and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Confounding factors have the following characteristics: Associated with both disease and the risk factor Distributed unequally among the two groups It itself is a risk factor for causing the disease

questions.text: Group of people worked at uranium mines for 5 years. Among them few developed cancer due to  uranium exposure. Which type of association would it be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Temporal association

Time dimension” i.e. the risk factor happened “BEFORE” the disease. Hence the answer – temporality.

choices.text: Weight for height below 2SD of WHO growth standards 2006

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with severe malnutrition. The child is lethargic, has a swollen abdomen, and exhibits signs of edema. The child is not able to consume solid foods and has a poor appetite and was suspected of having Acute malnutrition. Acute severe malnutrition diagnostic criteria include all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Weight for height below 2SD of WHO growth standards 2006

Severe malnutrition has two extreme forms, viz Marasmus (More common and Less serious) and Kwashiorkor. WHO defines Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) as Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm (Age 6–59 months) Weight-for-Height z-score < –3 Presence of bilateral pedal edema in children with kwashiorkor SAM can also be diagnosed by assessing children for visible severe wasting (muscle wasting in gluteal region), loss of subcutaneous fat or prominence of bony structures (thorax).

choices.text: Mid year population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year
Mid year women population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year
Mid year married women between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year of age
Live births in the same year

questions.text: General fertility rate is a better measure of fertility in defining GFR , which of the following is taken as the denominator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mid year women population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year

Explanation : GFR is the no of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group ( 15 to 44 or 49 years) in a given year. It is better measure of fertility than crude birth rate , but it’s limitation is that not all women are exposed to risk of child birth.

questions.text: A women with parity index of P1 L1 A1 comes to opd on her 44th post natal day for her routine checkup with a history of ectopic pregnancy previously , while considering spacing which of the following method should be deferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mirena

Explanation : History of ectopic pregnancy rules out the insertion of IUCD’s . Mirena is a gen 3 or hormonal IUCD, hence Mirena should be deferred.

questions.text: A 8-month-old child had history of unusual cry and convulsions following previous vaccination after BCG, DPT, OPV-1 and Hepatitis B. Now parents have brought the child for next dose of vaccination. Which vaccine is contraindicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

DPT

Contraindications to DPT Vaccine: Seriously ill child, History of severe reaction (collapse or shock, persistent screaming episodes, temperature >40°C, convulsions, other neurological symptoms and anaphylactic reactions) after a previous dose. In such cases subsequent immunization with DT only is recommended

questions.text: Which of the following mosquito is important regarding the international travel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aedes aegypti

It is important from prevention of yellow fever epidemic. Under the international health regulations. The policy for prevention of yellow fever is known as EYE strategy. Elimination of yellow fever epidemic.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect match of the Vaccine & the Strain used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

BCG: Urabe

Four BCG strains, French 1173-P2, Danish 1331, Japanese 172 and Glaxo-1077, among those most widely used throughout the world for tuberculosis vaccination, were prepared according to the respective conditions in each BCG-production unit. Commonly used mumps vaccine strain is the Urabe AM9 strain, which consists of a mixture of mumps viruses that differ at a single codon of the hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) gene.

questions.text: A young girl with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phrynoderma

A child having night-blindness, and multiple keratotic papules on elbows as shown in the image suggests a diagnosis of phrynoderma or toad-skin. This can occur due to the deficiency of vitamin A.

questions.text: Shown sign can be demonstrated in which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above

Auspitz sign refers to pinpoint bleeding under the skin's surface. It typically occurs after scratching psoriasis plaques or other forms of skin scales. Although the Auspitz sign may indicate that an individual has psoriasis, actinic keratoses, or Darier disease, it is not a clear marker of diagnosis. Auspitz sign is NOT specificfor Chronic plaque Psoriasis because it is also seen in Darier's disease and Actinic keratosis.

questions.text: Burrows in scabies involve which layer of skin:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stratum corneum

Scabies occurs worldwide and is a common skin condition. The infestation begins with the female mite burrowing within the stratum corneum of its host where it lays its eggs. It later develops into larvae, nymphs, and adults.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with the skin lesions depicted in the image. Diascopy reveals apple jelly nodules. Her serum angiotensin- converting enzyme levels were higher than normal. What is the possible diagnosis of shown condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lupus pernio

The image given is of lupus pernio seen in sarcoidosis. Work up:
1.	CXR : Egg shell calcification
2.	IOC: LN biopsy
3.	Gallium scan : Panda sign
4.	ACE levels increased

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to OPD concerned about “white” spots on his arms and legs. Spots have been present for many years and are asymptomatic & was diagnosed as Vitiligo. Which stain can be used for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fontana masson

Fontana Masson stains melanin pigment. Any cell containing melanin will stain black. Fontana Masson stain in case of Vitiligo shows no positive staining (no black melanin pigment).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with acute onset of diffuse hair loss in clumps in scalp region of a week's duration. The patient was taking azathioprine tablet for	cutaneous	leukocytoclastic vasculitis. What is possible hair disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anagen effluvium

Anagen effluvium is a nonscarring alopecia may be triggered by chemotherapeutic agents (antimetabolites, alkylating agents, and mitotic inhibitors) and usually occurs within 14 days of treatment.

questions.text: A middle aged female has flaccid bullae in the skin and oral erosion. Histopathology shows intra-epidermal acantholoytic blisters. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pemphigus vulgaris

Flaacid intraepidermal bullae with oral erosions are seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: Odland bodies are seen in which layer of epidermis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stratum granulosum

Odland bodies are membrane coated granules in stratum granulosum, which contain lipids which is responsible for barrier function of this layer.

questions.text: A known case of diabetes develops annular orange skin lesions, which disappear after biopsy. This phe- nomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Koebner's phenomenon

Annular orange skin lesions in diabetic indicate granuloma annulare. There have been few reports of disappearance of lesions after biopsy in granuloma annulare known as reverse Koebner's phenomenon

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of palpitations and has a regular heartbeat at a rate of 170/min, with a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. The rate abruptly changes to 75/min after applying carotid sinus pressure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

The patient most likely has PSVT, since the tachycardia terminates after carotid sinus massage (CSM). CSM increases vagal tone (parasympathetic) which decreases AV nodal conduction and terminates AV node re-entry arrhythmias.

choices.text: A deep S wave in lead I
Depressed ST segments in leads I and II
Prominent Q wave in lead I, and inversion of T wave in lead III

questions.text: A 42-year-old man develops shortness of breath (SOB) and chest pain 7 days after an open cholecystectomy. His blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, respirations 24/min, and oxygen saturation of 97%. Pulmonary embolism is clinically suspected. Which of the following is the most specific ECG finding of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

prominent Q wave in lead I, and inversion of T wave in lead III

Sinus tachycardia is the most common ECG finding in pulmonary embolism. The specific ECG signs of pulmonary embolism such as the S1, Q3, T3 are rarely seen except in cases of massive pulmonary embolism. In submassive pulmonary emboli, the ECG may show nonspecific ST changes and sinus tachycardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with SOB, fatigue, and edema. He has also noticed weight gain, abdominal discomfort, and distension. He has a prior history of lung cancer treated with radiotherapy to the chest. There is no history of liver or cardiac disease in the past. On examination, he has an elvated JVP, prominent y descent of neck veins, and positive Kussmaul’s sign. The heart sounds are normal. The CXR shows a normal cardiac silhouette and the ECG has low voltages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Constrictive pericarditis

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by a prominent y descent of the neck veins and low voltage on ECG. The presence of a positive Kussmaul’s sign helps differentiate the syndrome from cor pulmonale and restrictive cardiomyopathies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with diabetes presents with lesions on her leg. They are not painful and have a central depression and raised irregular margin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

This lesion is more frequent in females and may antedate other clinical signs and symptoms of diabetes. The plaques are round, firm, and reddish-brown to yellow in color. They most commonly involve the legs but can also involve the hands, arms, abdomen, and head.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common manifestation of multiple endocrine neoplasia, type I (MEN I)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

primary hyperparathyroidism

Primary hyperparathyroidism develops in over 87% of those with MEN I.

choices.text: Increased risk of breast & pancreatic cancer

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman was diagnosed 7 years earlier with precocious pseudopuberty secondary to ovarian tumor. Physical examination reveals oral and lingual dark pigmentation. Which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Autosomal recessive

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing noncancerous polyps and cancerous tumors.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents with diarrhea. He also complains of facial flushing lasting minutes at a time. Physical examination reveals facial telangiectasias and a heart murmur not present 2 years before. This murmur is accentuated by deep breathing. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

urinary 5-hydroxyindolacetic acid (5-HIAA)

The syndrome is characteristic of carcinoid of midgut origin. The cardiac lesions are more common on the right side (hence murmur accentuation on deep inspiration). Foregut carcinoids (bronchus, stomach, duodenum) frequently are associated with wheezing. The most important mediator of the carcinoid syndrome is serotonin. Serotonin is rapidly metabolized to 5-HIAA, which is rapidly cleared by the kidneys. The measurement of 5-HIAA in the urine is thus the most useful diagnostic test. Its specificity is enhanced by an appropriate diet before testing.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man, recently discharged from the hospital, develops severe diarrhea and abdominal pain. Sigmoidoscopy reveals a granular friable mucosa. Which of the following is the most common cause of this syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cephalosporin therapy This likely represents diarrhea secondary to Clostridium difficile infection. It is mediated by toxins, not by direct bacterial invasion. Cephalosporins, because they are so widely used, are the most common cause of the disease.

choices.text: Tissue transglutaminase IgA is highly sensitive & specific

questions.text: A 19-year-old man has a long history of weight loss, abdominal distention, bloating, and diarrhea. Investigation reveals steatorrhea, and a small bowel biopsy reveals blunting and flattening of villi. Which of the following is not associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All are correct

This syndrome is likely celiac sprue, but a clinical and histologic improvement with a gluten-free diet would be required for confirmation. The decrease in pancreatic enzyme production is secondary to decreased intestinal secretion of hormones that stimulate the pancreas. Dermatitis herpetiformis  
might be related to celiac disease. Although gross malabsorption is the classical description of celiac sprue, it can present with isolated deficiencies such as iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is seen for asymptomatic elevations in his AST and ALT. He appears well and the physical examination is normal. There is no prior history of intravenous drug use, blood transfusions, or multiple sex partners. His hepatitis serology is positive for the virus, most likely to lead to chronic infection. Which of the following is most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

hepatitis C virus

Chronic hepatitis C infection occurs in 80–90% of patients. About 50–70% will have evidence of chronic liver disease. In contrast, only 1–10% of adults infected with hepatitis B will go on to chronic infection.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML-M3). Which of the following is a characteristic of this acute myelogenous leukemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Auer bodies in blast cells

Auer bodies are slender, pink, staining rods containing lysozyme, and are exclusively seen in AML. Although similar to normal azurophilic granules in content and staining properties, they are distinguished by their gigantic size. Special stains can enhance the detection of Auer bodies. They are only seen in a minority of cases. The Philadelphia chromosome is a feature of choric myelogenous leukemia (CML), and a high leukocyte alkaline phosphatase level is seen in patients with a high WBC due to a leukemoid reaction.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man developed a transient episode of vertigo, slurred speech, diplopia, and paresthesias. He is symptom-free now, and clinical examination is entirely normal. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause for symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Posterior circulation transient ischemic attack (TIA)

Posterior circulation TIAis suggested by the transient episodes. The basilar artery is formed by the two vertebral arteries and supplies the pons, the midbrain, and the cerebellum. With vertebrobasilar TIAs, tinnitus, vertigo, diplopia, ataxia, hemiparesis, and bilateral visual impairment are common findings.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of episodes of severe unilateral, stabbing facial pain that is intermittent for several hours, and then disappears for several days. Physical examination is entirely normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

trigeminal neuralgia
The cause of trigeminal neuralgia is unknown, although some cases may be caused by compression of the trigeminal nerve by arteries or veins of the posterior fossa. The pain occurs in paroxysms and is strictly limited to one or more branches of the fifth cranial nerve. Paroxysms may be brief or last up to 15 minutes. There is no objective sensory loss, but the patient may complain of hyperesthesia of the face. Watering of the eye on the involved side may occur during an attack.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has multiple tan-colored patches on his skin, and freckle-like skin changes in his armpit area. The rest of clinical examination is normal. Which of the following conditions is also found in patients with this disorder as they get older?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Multiple cutaneous and subcutaneous tumors

The two common forms of neurofibromatosis (NF-1 and NF-2) are genetically distinct. NF-1 is the type with multiple café au lait spots and is associated with axillary or inguinal freckling, iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules), peripheral neurofibromas, and bony abnormalities (including kyphoscoliosis). NF-2 is associated with CNS tumors, particularly bilateral eighth nerve tumors. Skin lesions are spare or absent, and early lens opacities can occur.

questions.text: A man with symptoms of sinusitis and an incidental finding in the skull. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Paget’s disease

This is a rarefied area involving the frontal and parietal bones, and it is an early stage of Paget’s disease
in which calvarial thickening and foci or radiopacity are not present within the radiolucent area.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for eye symptom associated with a 20 year old male having back stiffness and shown radiological finding (it is the most common extra-articular manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute anterior uveitis
Acute anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Pain, photophobia, and increased lacrimation are the usual symptoms. Attacks are unilateral and tend to recur, often in the other eye.
